pullRequest.body:
Formulae for Hurwitz zeta functions at negative integers in terms of Bernoulli polynomials.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: Thanks for the review, Filippo! I've applied all the changes you suggested, except one which didn't seem to compile.

> Thanks for the review, Filippo! I've applied all the changes you suggested, except one which didn't seem to compile.

I have proposed something new that seems to compile.

> > Thanks for the review, Filippo! I've applied all the changes you suggested, except one which didn't seem to compile.
> 
> I have proposed something new that seems to compile.

Thanks, it builds fine now with that fix. Let me know if you're happy with the code now, if so I'll ping one of the maintainers to merge it.

> > > Thanks for the review, Filippo! I've applied all the changes you suggested, except one which didn't seem to compile.
> > 
> > 
> > I have proposed something new that seems to compile.
> 
> Thanks, it builds fine now with that fix. Let me know if you're happy with the code now, if so I'll ping one of the maintainers to merge it.

Yes, I am perfectly happy with the code.

:v: loefflerd can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Hi Riccardo,

Thanks for the review! 

Re namespaces: all of the results currently in Mathlib about the Hurwitz and Riemann zeta functions are currently in the root namespace. I'm happy to discuss moving them into a separate namespace of their own, but I feel that should be orthogonal to this PR; it clearly wouldn't make sense to namespace just the new lemmas from this PR without doing the same to the already-extant ones. So if it's OK with you, I'm going to merge this PR once CI passes.

Best wishes, David

> Hi Riccardo,
> 
> Thanks for the review!
> 
> Re namespaces: all of the results currently in Mathlib about the Hurwitz and Riemann zeta functions are currently in the root namespace. I'm happy to discuss moving them into a separate namespace of their own, but I feel that should be orthogonal to this PR; it clearly wouldn't make sense to namespace just the new lemmas from this PR without doing the same to the already-extant ones. So if it's OK with you, I'm going to merge this PR once CI passes.
> 
> Best wishes, David

Yes, this can be done in another PR.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

> Hi Riccardo,
> 
> Thanks for the review!
> 
> Re namespaces: all of the results currently in Mathlib about the Hurwitz and Riemann zeta functions are currently in the root namespace. I'm happy to discuss moving them into a separate namespace of their own, but I feel that should be orthogonal to this PR; it clearly wouldn't make sense to namespace just the new lemmas from this PR without doing the same to the already-extant ones. So if it's OK with you, I'm going to merge this PR once CI passes.
> 
> Best wishes, David

Yes, putting all these results in a namespace could be useful (for instance, thinking ahead at when we will have more general Dedekind zera, something like `residue_zeta` might be in the `RiemannZeta` or in `DedekindZeta` namespaces). For the next PR...

I think this results should go in some namespace, but otherwise LGTM, thanks!

bors d+
Nice work!

I think this results should go in some namespace, but otherwise LGTM, thanks!

bors d+
Do you want to add a date to make "present time" clearer?

This and most of the lemmas below express an "easy"  LHS in terms of a "complicated" RHS. I understand that this is closer to the mathematician's idea that we are "expressing the Hurwitz zeta in terms of..." but I wonder if the opposite would not be more natural given the library design. Do you already have applications showing that these directions are more useful than the opposite ones?

That’s an Interesting point, but I think I disagree about which side is “complicated”. The RHS is lengthy to write down but all the terms are elementary in some sense (particularly for the lemmas with `s < 0`, where the RHS is a rational number and algorithmically computable [edit : for `x` rational], while the LHS takes literally thousands of lines of code to even define.) E.g. in “zeta(-1) = 1/12” I think it’s clear which side is the easy one!

Yes, I see what you mean and I also agree that the direction you chose is the best one. I was more thinking about "is a mathematician's and a mathlib-ician's definition of "easy" the same one"? One can argue that "simple things" are goal states you are happy with, and "hard ones" are goal states you are unhappy with. If the above lemma is typically used to transform the RHS into a value of the cosZeta function, that it shuold be changed, but if it is meant to unwind coZeta(2k) than this is the right direction (same idea as for simp). For the code at hand I do not want to suggest modifications, after all, I was just opening the discussion ;-)
Indeed, it's meant as a way to "unwind" cosZeta(2k) in terms of more elementary things (as a step towards formulae like zeta(2) = pi^2 / 6).

```suggestion
  rw [Nat.cast_succ, show (1 : ℂ) - 2 * (k + 1) = - 2 * k - 1 by ring,
    hurwitzZetaOdd_neg_two_mul_nat_sub_one]
```

```suggestion
  rw [(by simp : 2 * (k : ℂ) + 1 = ↑(2 * k + 1)), cpow_natCast]
  ring
```

```suggestion
  norm_num
  rw [(by simp : 2 * (k : ℂ) = ↑(2 * k)), cpow_natCast]
  ring
```
I tried applying this change, but it didn't compile. Maybe there was a typo? Could you take another look and let me know what you intended here?

I am sorry, it was a bad copy-pasting. The following compiles for me:

```suggestion
  norm_cast
  ring_nf
```
Thanks, that works indeed!

```suggestion
theorem cosZeta_two_mul_nat (hk : k ≠ 0) (hx : x ∈ Icc 0 1) :
```

```suggestion
theorem sinZeta_two_mul_nat_add_one (hk : k ≠ 0) (hx : x ∈ Icc 0 1) :
    sinZeta x (2 * k + 1) = (-1) ^ (k + 1) * (2 * π) ^ (2 * k + 1) / 2 / (2 * k + 1)! *
      ((Polynomial.bernoulli (2 * k + 1)).map (algebraMap ℚ ℂ)).eval (x : ℂ) := by
```
I think `(x : ℂ)` is more readable, but as you prefer.
Same comments as above (and also in the declarations below).

source.title: Tracking issue for Hurwitz and Dirichlet L-series
